articles.headline: Liberals Hope Elizabeth Warren Will Serve as Clinton’s Scrutinizer in Chief
articles.snippet: With polls showing that Hillary Clinton is likely to prevail in the election, liberal Democrats are beginning to exert pressure over her potential appointments.
articles.abstract: With polls showing that Hillary Clinton is likely to prevail in the election, liberal Democrats are beginning to exert pressure over her potential appointments.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Elizabeth Warren delivered a blistering rebuke of Donald J. Trump on Monday, warning him that “nasty women vote” and imploring a crowd to cast ballots for Hillary Clinton.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Matt Flegenheimer

articles.headline: AARP Sues U.S. Over Rules for Wellness Programs
articles.snippet: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission’s rules allow employers to offer up to 30 percent off health insurance coverage for participants.
articles.abstract: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission’s rules allow employers to offer up to 30 percent off health insurance coverage for participants.
articles.lead_paragraph: Employers have raced to offer workers a hefty financial incentive to sign up for programs meant to improve their health, submitting personal medical details in the process. But as these programs have spread, so has resistance from employees dubious about sharing that information with employers.

articles.headline: As Europe and Asia Hoard Cash, Economists See Echoes of Crisis
articles.snippet: Foreign investors are rushing to plow cash into the United States bond market, recalling a wave of investment in mortgage-backed securities in the 2000s.
articles.abstract: Foreign investors are rushing to plow cash into the United States bond market, recalling a wave of investment in mortgage-backed securities in the 2000s.
articles.lead_paragraph: European and Asian investors have been rushing into the United States bond market, spurred by a global glut of savings that has reached record levels.

articles.headline: With AT&T-Time Warner Deal Brewing, a Focus on Preserving CNN’s Integrity
articles.snippet: The difficulties of defending tough reporting and shielding journalists from powerful antagonists can be hard for any corporation to stomach. And AT&T has no journalistic lineage.
articles.abstract: The difficulties of defending tough reporting and shielding journalists from powerful antagonists can be hard for any corporation to stomach. And AT&T has no journalistic lineage.
articles.lead_paragraph: In its 130-year history, AT&T has transitioned from a telegraph service to a wireless provider to a global communications behemoth.

articles.headline: Some Health Plan Costs to Increase by an Average of 25 Percent, U.S. Says
articles.snippet: Consumers in some states will also find significantly fewer insurance companies offering coverage under the Affordable Care Act.
articles.abstract: Consumers in some states will also find significantly fewer insurance companies offering coverage under the Affordable Care Act.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Premiums for midlevel health plans under the Affordable Care Act will increase by an average of 25 percent next year, while consumers in some states will find significantly fewer insurance companies offering coverage, the federal government said Monday.

articles.headline: AT&T-Time Warner Deal Is a Shot in the Dark
articles.snippet: AT&T’s $85 billion deal for Time Warner is a ploy to do something — anything — in the face of a rapidly changing media landscape.
articles.abstract: AT&T’s $85 billion deal for Time Warner is a ploy to do something — anything — in the face of a rapidly changing media landscape.
articles.lead_paragraph: The official rationale for AT&T’s $85 billion deal to purchase Time Warner is that in uncertain times, bigger is better.

articles.headline: A Chilly Reaction to AT&T-Time Warner Deal
articles.snippet: A look at where the AT&T deal leaves other prominent media companies and what some think they might attempt to do in response.
articles.abstract: A look at where the AT&T deal leaves other prominent media companies and what some think they might attempt to do in response.
articles.lead_paragraph: The $85 billion AT&T deal for Time Warner won’t win regulatory approval. We will continue our current course even if it does. Will a line of major media consolidation dominoes — involving titans like Disney, Fox and Comcast — begin to fall? Not likely.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Emily Steel

articles.headline: Resettling China’s ‘Ecological Migrants’
articles.snippet: Miaomiao Lake Village is just one of the new communities built to accommodate the world’s largest environmental migration project. But residents are struggling to adapt.
articles.abstract: Miaomiao Lake Village is just one of the new communities built to accommodate the world’s largest environmental migration project. But residents are struggling to adapt.
articles.lead_paragraph: Miaomiao Lake Village is just one of the new communities built to accommodate the world’s largest environmental migration project. But residents are struggling to adapt.

articles.headline: The Pentagon’s ‘Terminator Conundrum’: Robots That Could Kill on Their Own
articles.snippet: The United States has put artificial intelligence at the center of its defense strategy, with weapons that can identify targets and make decisions.
articles.abstract: The United States has put artificial intelligence at the center of its defense strategy, with weapons that can identify targets and make decisions.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAMP EDWARDS, Mass. — The small drone, with its six whirring rotors, swept past the replica of a Middle Eastern village and closed in on a mosque-like structure, its camera scanning for targets.
articles.byline: By Matthew Rosenberg and John Markoff

articles.headline: As ID Laws Fall, Voters See New Barriers Rise
articles.snippet: Contrasting laws and rulings leave election officials and voters confused, and some court remedies fall well short of restoring previous access to the voting booth.
articles.abstract: Contrasting laws and rulings leave election officials and voters confused, and some court remedies fall well short of restoring previous access to the voting booth.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. — It seemed a clear victory for voting rights advocates in July when a federal court invalidated much of Wisconsin’s restrictive elections law, concluding that it discriminated against minorities by requiring voters to produce photo identification cards that blacks and Latinos too often lack. The remedy was straightforward: Henceforth, the state was to “promptly issue a credential valid as a voting ID to any person” who applied for one.

articles.headline: AT&T Cheerleading Squad for Merger: Nearly 100 Lobbyists
articles.snippet: As a multimillion-dollar donor to lawmakers, with a huge roster of lobbyists, the communications giant is ready to pursue its $85 billion bid for Time Warner.
articles.abstract: As a multimillion-dollar donor to lawmakers, with a huge roster of lobbyists, the communications giant is ready to pursue its $85 billion bid for Time Warner.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — From the political right and the left, AT&T’s $85 billion bid for Time Warner has provoked pushback. But AT&T, in addition to its billions of dollars of capital, has another arsenal at its disposal: one of the most formidable lobbying operations in Washington.
articles.byline: By Cecilia Kang and Eric Lipton

articles.headline: What Drives Donald Trump? Fear of Losing Status, Tapes Show
articles.snippet: In more than five hours of conversations — the last extensive biographical interviews he granted before running for president — Mr. Trump makes clear how difficult it is for him to imagine, let alone accept, defeat.
articles.abstract: In more than five hours of conversations — the last extensive biographical interviews he granted before running for president — Mr. Trump makes clear how difficult it is for him to imagine, let alone accept, defeat.
articles.lead_paragraph: By any measure, Arsenio Hall was a Hollywood success: He had starred in popular films, packed houses as a stand-up comic and hosted a hit late-night television show bearing his name.

articles.headline: If Immigration Can’t Be Stopped, Maybe It Can Be Managed
articles.snippet: The United States can choose what kind of low-skilled immigration it will have, legal or illegal, and specialists say legal is undoubtedly better.
articles.abstract: The United States can choose what kind of low-skilled immigration it will have, legal or illegal, and specialists say legal is undoubtedly better.
articles.lead_paragraph: Can anything be done about illegal immigration?
